headline.main: The Writer, the State and the Nobel

docs.abstract: A writer with the pen name Don't Speak, an allusion to the fear of getting into trouble in a one-party state, becomes a top literary official of that state &#8212 and wins the world's biggest literary award. Fiction? No - it just happened.
docs.snippet: A writer with the pen name Don't Speak, an allusion to the fear of getting into trouble in a one-party state, becomes a top literary official of that state &#8212 and wins the world's biggest literary award. Fiction? No - it just happened.

headline.seo: Biden vs. Ryan: No Shy People Onstage
headline.main: Biden vs. Ryan: No Shy People Onstage

docs.abstract: News analysis; Vice President Joseph R Biden Jr and Rep Paul D Ryan, in lively and sometimes fiery vice-presidential debate, hold their positions tenaciously and delineate battle lines that had been blurred when President Obama and Mitt Romney met in the previous week; how much change American voters are ready for may determine whom they side with in days to come.
docs.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan held their positions tenaciously and delineated battle lines that had been blurred when President Obama and Mitt Romney met a week ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s campaign has decided time on debate preparation is time well spent, even at the cost of voter rallies.

headline.seo: Obama Tries to Balance Debate Practice and Rallies
headline.main: After Fiery Florida Rally, Obama Focuses on Debate Work
headline.print_headline: A Fiery Rally, Then More Debate Study for Obama

docs.abstract: Pres Obama will spend more time preparing for the second presidential debate than the first, following a poor initial performance; shift will leave the president less time for the voter rallies that tend to showcase his talent for oratory.
docs.snippet: The president’s campaign has decided time on debate preparation is time well spent, even at the cost of voter rallies.

byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Coral Gables, and Trip Gabriel from Asheville, N.C.

docs.lead_paragraph: Diana Reed received a series of steroid injections to alleviate her neck pain. She later died, one of more than 130 people to have contracted meningitis in a national outbreak.

headline.main: After a Meningitis Death, Family Members Ask Why
headline.print_headline: After a Meningitis Death, Loved Ones Ask Why

docs.abstract: Twelve people have died so far and more than 130 have become ill in meningitis outbreak related to spinal injections of tainted steroid produced by Massachusetts pharmacy New England Compounding Center; family members struggle with the question of why better safeguards were not in place to protect their loved ones.
docs.snippet: Diana Reed received a series of steroid injections to alleviate her neck pain. She later died, one of more than 130 people to have contracted meningitis in a national outbreak.

byline.contributor: Sabrina Tavernise contributed reporting from Boston.
